citation.article-title: Flaviramulus basaltis gen. nov., sp. nov., a novel member of the family Flavobacteriaceae isolated from seafloor basalt.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Flaviramulus basaltis sp. nov.
Flaviramulus basaltis (ba.sal′tis. L. masc. gen. n. basaltis of basalt, pertaining to the source of isolation).
Has the following properties in addition to those given for the genus.
Colonies grown on MA are shiny, dark yellow, circular, convex, with an entire margin.
Cells are catalase-positive, oxidase-negative and alkaline phosphatase-positive.
Growth occurs from −2.0 to 34.0 °C, with optimum growth at 17.5–22.8 °C.
The salinity range for growth is 3–60 g sea salts l−1, with an optimum of 24–60 g l−1.
Growth is supported at pH 6.5–8.6, with optimum growth at pH 6.5–8.2.
Requires seawater, yeast extract or thiamine and amino acids for growth.
Utilizes and produces acids from several sugars.
Utilizes organic acids and amino acids.
Hydrolyses l-tyrosine, aesculin, carrageenan, gelatin, starch, DNA, urea, and Tweens 20, 40 and 80, but not agar, cellulose or chitin.
Mean DNA G+C content is 31.4±0.6 mol% (sd) as determined by the thermal denaturation method.
The type strain, H35T (=CIP 109091T=DSM 18180T), was isolated from seafloor basalt offshore of Jan Mayen in the Norwegian/Greenland Sea at a depth of 1300 m.
